elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0005">
<ce:label>Fig. 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="cn0005">
<ce:simple-para id="sp0020" view="all">(a) The ORTEP representation of crystal structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> with thermal ellipsoid at 30% probability level. H atoms are omitted for clarity (b) The 2-D network found in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (an O–Ag–O chain is highlighted by ball-stick representation). (c) The 20-membered macrocycles composed of four silver(I) centers showing aromatic C–H⋯π contact.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link id="lk00005" locator="gr1" xlink:href="pii:S0277538716306428/gr1" xlink:role="http://data.elsevier.com/vocabulary/ElsevierContentTypes/23.4" xlink:type="simple"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 1  (a) The ORTEP representation of crystal structure of 1 with thermal ellipsoid at 30% probability level. H atoms are omitted for clarity (b) The 2-D network found in 1 (an O-Ag-O chain is highlighted by ball-stick representation). (c) The 20-membered macrocycles composed of four silver(I) centers showing aromatic C-H⋯π contact.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0010">
<ce:label>Fig. 2</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="cn0010">
<ce:simple-para id="sp0025" view="all">(a) The ORTEP representation of partial structure of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> with thermal ellipsoid at 30% probability level. H atoms are omitted for clarity. (b) The 2-D coordination network revealed in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. (c) The 3-D framework found in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> viewing down the crystallographic <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> axis. (d) A TOPOS representation of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> showing a uninodal {6^6} net.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link id="lk00010" locator="gr2" xlink:href="pii:S0277538716306428/gr2" xlink:role="http://data.elsevier.com/vocabulary/ElsevierContentTypes/23.4" xlink:type="simple"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 2  (a) The ORTEP representation of partial structure of 2 with thermal ellipsoid at 30% probability level. H atoms are omitted for clarity. (b) The 2-D coordination network revealed in 2. (c) The 3-D framework found in 2 viewing down the crystallographic c axis. (d) A TOPOS representation of 2 showing a uninodal {6^6} net.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0015">
<ce:label>Fig. 3</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="cn0015">
<ce:simple-para id="sp0030" view="all">(a) ORTEP representation of the repeating unit in the network of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> with ellipsoids plotted at the 30% probability level. H atoms are omitted for clarity. (b) Ball-stick representation for one of the saddle-like grid containing a PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anion in the center. (c) Part of the 2-D grid-like network observed in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions are omitted for clarity.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link id="lk00015" locator="gr3" xlink:href="pii:S0277538716306428/gr3" xlink:role="http://data.elsevier.com/vocabulary/ElsevierContentTypes/23.4" xlink:type="simple"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 3  (a) ORTEP representation of the repeating unit in the network of 3 with ellipsoids plotted at the 30% probability level. H atoms are omitted for clarity. (b) Ball-stick representation for one of the saddle-like grid containing a PF6 - anion in the center. (c) Part of the 2-D grid-like network observed in 3. PF6 - anions are omitted for clarity.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0020">
<ce:label>Fig. 4</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="cn0020">
<ce:simple-para id="sp0035" view="all">(a) The repeat unit in the crystal structure of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> with ellipsoids plotted at the 50% probability level. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. (b) One of the racemic helical chains (<ce:italic>M-</ce:italic>helix) found in the structure of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, and the helical chain is highlighted with red color. (Colour online.)</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link id="lk00020" locator="gr4" xlink:href="pii:S0277538716306428/gr4" xlink:role="http://data.elsevier.com/vocabulary/ElsevierContentTypes/23.4" xlink:type="simple"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 4  (a) The repeat unit in the crystal structure of 4 with ellipsoids plotted at the 50% probability level. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. (b) One of the racemic helical chains (M-helix) found in the structure of 4, and the helical chain is highlighted with red color. (Colour online.)

</ce:caption>

</ce:figure>

</ce:caption>

<ce:section-title id="st005">Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">Four new silver(I) coordination polymers based on a flexible thioether 1,3-bis(methylthiomethyl)benzene have been synthesized and structurally characterized by X-ray crystallography. The anion effect on the structural diversity of various silver(I) networks was studied.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

Four new silver(I) coordination polymers based on a flexible thioether 1,3-bis(methylthiomethyl)benzene have been synthesized and structurally characterized by X-ray crystallography. The anion effect on the structural diversity of various silver(I) networks was studied.

elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A flexible thioether ligand, 1,3-bis(methylthiomethyl)benzene (L) has been employed to prepare supramolecular assemblies with silver salts of various anions such as NO3 -, BF4 -, PF6 - and SbF6 -. X-ray structural analysis reveals that even though the same metal ion (Ag+) and ligand (L) were used to react under the same conditions, anions have played a critical role in driving the variation of metal-ligand binding modes as well as network topologies of the resultant coordination polymers. The reaction of L with silver nitrate resulted in a 2-D coordination network 1, composed of metallomacrocycles bridged with NO3 - ions. A 3-D framework 2 was observed when silver tetrafluoroborate was used. Although BF4 - ions were not involved in coordinating with metal centers, the participation of water molecules led to a different metal-ligand binding mode and hence the formation of a network with higher dimension. The large, non-coordinating anion PF6 - was found to be responsible for the assembly of a 2-D grid-like network 3, in which interesting 4+4 metallocycles occupied with PF6 - ions were disclosed. However, the presence of a larger anion analog, SbF6 - simplified the network structure to form a 1-D helical chain (4) through the coordination of solvent molecules (CH3CN) with silver(I) centers.

<ce:section-title id="st020">Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">The structural topology and dimensionality of metal–organic coordination networks play a key role in regulating their physical and materials properties . In this regard, the rational design of network structures through judicious selection of metal sources and organic ligands has been the center of recent research efforts in order to fabricate materials with desired properties and functionality . While the variation of both organic ligands and metal cations was believed to determine the formation of diverse coordination complexes or networks of one- to three-dimensions (1–3D), other factors including counter anions, solvents and reaction conditions have also great impact on the structural diversity of the resultant metal–organic coordination architectures . Amongst those, the role of anions in governing the self-assembly process of metals and organic ligands, and hence the supermolecular structures of coordination assemblies has been highlighted in recent reports .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The structural topology and dimensionality of metal-organic coordination networks play a key role in regulating their physical and materials properties . In this regard, the rational design of network structures through judicious selection of metal sources and organic ligands has been the center of recent research efforts in order to fabricate materials with desired properties and functionality . While the variation of both organic ligands and metal cations was believed to determine the formation of diverse coordination complexes or networks of one- to three-dimensions (1-3D), other factors including counter anions, solvents and reaction conditions have also great impact on the structural diversity of the resultant metal-organic coordination architectures . Amongst those, the role of anions in governing the self-assembly process of metals and organic ligands, and hence the supermolecular structures of coordination assemblies has been highlighted in recent reports .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0010" view="all">Whereas tremendous research efforts in metallosupramolecular and metal–organic materials chemistry have concerned the employment of nitrogen- and oxygen-donor ligands (typically polypyridine and carboxylate compounds) , sulfur-containing ligands remain less explored, probably owing to both their weak coordination ability with most transition metals and their poor thermal- and air-stability . To date, several types of macrocyclic and acyclic thioethers have been investigated for the construction of network solids with metal ions, and preferably silver ion has been popularly selected as a soft Lewis acid for sulfur coordination in these studies . In addition, Ag<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup> complexes proved to be attractive to chemists owing to their widespread applications in many aspects including photoluminescence materials, sensors, biochemistry and catalysis . However, the coordination versatility between thioether ligands and silver ions has been not fully explored, despite interesting coordination modes and unique structural features have been observed in some known silver-thioether complexes/networks .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Whereas tremendous research efforts in metallosupramolecular and metal-organic materials chemistry have concerned the employment of nitrogen- and oxygen-donor ligands (typically polypyridine and carboxylate compounds) , sulfur-containing ligands remain less explored, probably owing to both their weak coordination ability with most transition metals and their poor thermal- and air-stability . To date, several types of macrocyclic and acyclic thioethers have been investigated for the construction of network solids with metal ions, and preferably silver ion has been popularly selected as a soft Lewis acid for sulfur coordination in these studies . In addition, AgI complexes proved to be attractive to chemists owing to their widespread applications in many aspects including photoluminescence materials, sensors, biochemistry and catalysis . However, the coordination versatility between thioether ligands and silver ions has been not fully explored, despite interesting coordination modes and unique structural features have been observed in some known silver-thioether complexes/networks .

<ce:float-anchor refid="f0030"></ce:float-anchor>), and herein wish to report on the versatile self-assembly of this ligand with various silver(I) salts. It is revealed that new, diverse silver-thioether coordination networks could be attained based upon the use of different silver salts, and the counter anions (NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>

<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>) were found to significantly affect the coordination modes (

elements.clean_text: To extend our understanding on the silver(I) coordination chemistry of thioethers, we focus on an acyclic bidentate thioether ligand, 1,3-bis(methylthiomethyl)benzene (L), which adopts three types of ligand conformations while coordinating with metals ( ), and herein wish to report on the versatile self-assembly of this ligand with various silver(I) salts. It is revealed that new, diverse silver-thioether coordination networks could be attained based upon the use of different silver salts, and the counter anions (NO3 -, BF4 -, PF6 - and SbF6 -) were found to significantly affect the coordination modes ( ) and hence the supramolecular structures of the products.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st025">Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st030">General</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0020" view="all">Solvents and reagents were purchased from Fisher Scientific or Sigma–Aldrich in the US. All reactions were performed under ambient conditions (no inert atmosphere). FT-IR spectra were measured on a Shimadzu 8400S instrument with solid samples using a Golden Gate ATR accessory. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out on a Shimadzu TG-50 analyzer under N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> atmosphere with a heating rate of 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C/min. <ce:sup loc="pre">1</ce:sup>H NMR spectrum was obtained at room temperature on a Bruker III 500<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>MHz spectrometer with TMS as an internal standard. Elemental Analyses were performed by Midwest Microlab LLC in Indianapolis. Ligand L was synthesized according to a published procedure .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

General

Solvents and reagents were purchased from Fisher Scientific or Sigma-Aldrich in the US. All reactions were performed under ambient conditions (no inert atmosphere). FT-IR spectra were measured on a Shimadzu 8400S instrument with solid samples using a Golden Gate ATR accessory. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out on a Shimadzu TG-50 analyzer under N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 20°C/min. 1H NMR spectrum was obtained at room temperature on a Bruker III 500MHz spectrometer with TMS as an internal standard. Elemental Analyses were performed by Midwest Microlab LLC in Indianapolis. Ligand L was synthesized according to a published procedure .

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st035">Synthesis of Ag(L)(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)(<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0025" view="all">Ligand L (19.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) was dissolved in CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>–MeCN (10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL, 1:1, v/v) in a 25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL vial, to which an acetonitrile solution of AgNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (33.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) was added upon stirring at room temperature. The resulting solution was allowed to stir for 30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min and then filtered. Slow evaporation of the filtrate over 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>days gave colorless crystals, which were suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis. The product was collected by decanting the solvent and then washed with diethyl ether, and dried in the air. Yield: 30.9<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg (84% based on L). FT-IR (solid, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 2921w, 1432m, 1405s, 1277s, 1155w, 1083w, 1023m, 990w, 908w, 815s, 730s, 669w, 599w. <ce:italic>Anal.</ce:italic> Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">14</ce:inf>AgNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·0.2CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>: C, 31.80; H, 3.77; N, 3.64. Found C, 31.79; H, 3.60; N, 3.87%.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Ag(L)(NO3)(1)

Ligand L (19.8mg, 0.100mmol) was dissolved in CH2Cl2-MeCN (10mL, 1:1, v/v) in a 25mL vial, to which an acetonitrile solution of AgNO3 (33.8mg, 0.200mmol) was added upon stirring at room temperature. The resulting solution was allowed to stir for 30min and then filtered. Slow evaporation of the filtrate over 5days gave colorless crystals, which were suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis. The product was collected by decanting the solvent and then washed with diethyl ether, and dried in the air. Yield: 30.9mg (84% based on L). FT-IR (solid, cm-1): 2921w, 1432m, 1405s, 1277s, 1155w, 1083w, 1023m, 990w, 908w, 815s, 730s, 669w, 599w. Anal. Calc. for C10H14AgNO3S2⋅0.2CH2Cl2: C, 31.80; H, 3.77; N, 3.64. Found C, 31.79; H, 3.60; N, 3.87%.

<ce:section-title id="st055">X-ray structural determinations</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0045" view="all">Suitable crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> were mounted on Cryoloops with Paratone-N oil. Data were collected with a Bruker APEX II CCD using Mo Kα radiation and corrected for absorption with <ce:small-caps>sadabs</ce:small-caps> and structures solved by direct methods. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by full-matrix least squares on <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>. Hydrogen atoms were found from Fourier difference maps and refined isotropically, otherwise they were placed in calculated positions with appropriate riding parameters. Crystal structures and packing figures were drawn with the program Mercury v. 2.4 . The structural refinement details are summarized in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0005"></ce:float-anchor>. During the structural refinement of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> it was found that the main structure possessed multiple disorders: Ag(2) was modeled as disordered over two sites (0.46: 0.04); O(1) and O(2) were better refined while pushing off their special positions (<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>/<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, <ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>/<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>, z); The BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> counterions were found to possess three or two orientations that overlap. For the triple disorder, B(11):B(14):B(17) has a ratio of 0.38:0.38:0.24, and for the two position disorder, ratio of B(21):B(24) was 0.5:0.5. In addition, a lone peak indicated the presence of an additional contributor that has been assigned as a very low occupancy (∼25%) water molecule, O(31), without its hydrogen atoms being located or calculated. All full occupancy non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. A variety of restraints have been implemented to idealize the BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> groups, e.g. SIMU to restrain the thermal parameters, SADI to keep bond distances the same or nearly, and EADP to restrain atoms that are nearly overlapping to have the same thermal parameter.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray structural determinations

Suitable crystals of 1-4 were mounted on Cryoloops with Paratone-N oil. Data were collected with a Bruker APEX II CCD using Mo Kα radiation and corrected for absorption with sadabs and structures solved by direct methods. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by full-matrix least squares on F 2. Hydrogen atoms were found from Fourier difference maps and refined isotropically, otherwise they were placed in calculated positions with appropriate riding parameters. Crystal structures and packing figures were drawn with the program Mercury v. 2.4 . The structural refinement details are summarized in  . During the structural refinement of 2 it was found that the main structure possessed multiple disorders: Ag(2) was modeled as disordered over two sites (0.46: 0.04); O(1) and O(2) were better refined while pushing off their special positions (1/2, 3/4, z); The BF4 counterions were found to possess three or two orientations that overlap. For the triple disorder, B(11):B(14):B(17) has a ratio of 0.38:0.38:0.24, and for the two position disorder, ratio of B(21):B(24) was 0.5:0.5. In addition, a lone peak indicated the presence of an additional contributor that has been assigned as a very low occupancy (~25%) water molecule, O(31), without its hydrogen atoms being located or calculated. All full occupancy non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. A variety of restraints have been implemented to idealize the BF4 groups, e.g. SIMU to restrain the thermal parameters, SADI to keep bond distances the same or nearly, and EADP to restrain atoms that are nearly overlapping to have the same thermal parameter.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st060">Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st065">Synthesis and characterization of Ag(L)(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>) (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0050" view="all">Whereas cyclic thioethers were more extensively explored, studies on the coordination chemistry of discrete, acyclic thioethers were limited. L was chosen in this work, owing to its diverse molecular conformations and coordination versatility to silver(I) (), and that the ability of this type of ligands to form network polymers with silver(I) has been previously demonstrated from its structural analogs .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Synthesis and characterization of Ag(L)(NO3) (1)

Whereas cyclic thioethers were more extensively explored, studies on the coordination chemistry of discrete, acyclic thioethers were limited. L was chosen in this work, owing to its diverse molecular conformations and coordination versatility to silver(I) (), and that the ability of this type of ligands to form network polymers with silver(I) has been previously demonstrated from its structural analogs .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0055" view="all">The reaction of L with two equivalents of silver nitrate in a CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>–MeCN solution afforded after slow evaporation colorless crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> in high yield, that are suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis. Elemental analysis data reveals an empirical formula of Ag(L)NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, suggesting a 1:1 metal-to-ligand ratio in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is poorly soluble in common solvents, and slightly soluble in dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO). The <ce:sup loc="pre">1</ce:sup>HH NMR spectrum of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> in DMSO-<ce:italic>d</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> reveals only signals identical to those of the free ligand, indicating the decomposition of the complex in DMSO. In the IR spectrum of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> a strong band at around 1405<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> appeared due to the coordinated NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ions. X-ray structural analysis confirmed the formation of a coordination network involving effective Ag–S binding in the solid state (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>). <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>mc2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> and in the asymmetric unit there contains only one half of ligand L, one silver ion and nitrate anion, and the second half of L was generated by symmetry (operation code: −x, y, z). The Flack parameter of crystal <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> having a acentric space group was refined to be −0.01(2), indicating <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes as an enantiopure form, although achiral ligand was used. It was noticed that as seen in a the ligand molecules in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> adopt the conformation I and type-A binding mode with two silver(I) centers related by a <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> symmetric axis (). Relevant bond parameters around metal centers are summarized in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0010"></ce:float-anchor>. The silver(I) center is tetracoordinate with two sulfur atoms from symmetry-related ligands and two oxygen atoms of the bridging nitrate ions, being in a slightly distorted tetrahedral environment. The Ag-S bond distances are almost identical (2.5185(6) and 2.5186(6)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively), falling in the range of Ag–S bond lengths reported in the literature , yet the Ag–O bonds are slightly different in length (2.357(3) and 2.533(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). Propagation of the repeat structure unit along the silver(II) centers results in the formation of an infinite 2-D coordination network which is composed of 20-membered macrocycles containing two ligand units, two silver(I) centers and two bridging nitrato-O atoms (b and c). In each macrocycle, the Ag⋯Ag nonbonding distance between two silver(I) centers bonded to the same ligand is approximately 10.7<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, while the O-bridged Ag⋯Ag nonbonding distance is approximately 4.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The two phenyl rings of ligands in the macrocycle are arranged in an edge-to-face fashion and thus effective C–H⋯π interaction is observed between the rings. The C–H⋯ π (centroid) distance as illustrated in c is as short as ca. 2.85<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (c). It is worth mentioning that previously a silver(I) perchlorate complex based on a similar thioether ligand, 1,3-bis(phenylthiomethyl)benzene has been reported, where a structurally related grid-like network was observed . However, the structure of the repeating macrocyclic motif in this network is essentially distinct with that of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. In the structure reported previously , the silver centers are bridged by two oxygen atoms of the perchlorate anion, and the Ag–O bond distances are relatively longer (2.556(10) and 2.719(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively), indicating weaker bonding interactions. In addition, the phenyl rings in the macrocycle are arranged in a face-to-face mode by π⋯π stacking interaction (the distance between two aromatic planes is ca. 3.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), in sharp contrast to the C–H⋯π interactions found in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (c)</ce:para>

Elemental analysis data reveals an empirical formula of Ag(L)NO3, suggesting a 1:1 metal-to-ligand ratio in 1. 1 is poorly soluble in common solvents, and slightly soluble in dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO). The 1HH NMR spectrum of 1 in DMSO-d 6 reveals only signals identical to those of the free ligand, indicating the decomposition of the complex in DMSO. In the IR spectrum of 1 a strong band at around 1405cm-1 appeared due to the coordinated NO3 - ions. X-ray structural analysis confirmed the formation of a coordination network involving effective Ag-S binding in the solid state ( ). 1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Cmc21 and in the asymmetric unit there contains only one half of ligand L, one silver ion and nitrate anion, and the second half of L was generated by symmetry (operation code: -x, y, z). The Flack parameter of crystal 1 having a acentric space group was refined to be -0.01(2), indicating 1 crystallizes as an enantiopure form, although achiral ligand was used. It was noticed that as seen in a the ligand molecules in 1 adopt the conformation I and type-A binding mode with two silver(I) centers related by a C 2 symmetric axis (). Relevant bond parameters around metal centers are summarized in  . The silver(I) center is tetracoordinate with two sulfur atoms from symmetry-related ligands and two oxygen atoms of the bridging nitrate ions, being in a slightly distorted tetrahedral environment. The Ag-S bond distances are almost identical (2.5185(6) and 2.5186(6)Å, respectively), falling in the range of Ag-S bond lengths reported in the literature , yet the Ag-O bonds are slightly different in length (2.357(3) and 2.533(3)Å). Propagation of the repeat structure unit along the silver(II) centers results in the formation of an infinite 2-D coordination network which is composed of 20-membered macrocycles containing two ligand units, two silver(I) centers and two bridging nitrato-O atoms (b and c). In each macrocycle, the Ag⋯Ag nonbonding distance between two silver(I) centers bonded to the same ligand is approximately 10.7Å, while the O-bridged Ag⋯Ag nonbonding distance is approximately 4.6Å. The two phenyl rings of ligands in the macrocycle are arranged in an edge-to-face fashion and thus effective C-H⋯π interaction is observed between the rings. The C-H⋯ π (centroid) distance as illustrated in c is as short as ca. 2.85Å (c). In the structure reported previously , the silver centers are bridged by two oxygen atoms of the perchlorate anion, and the Ag-O bond distances are relatively longer (2.556(10) and 2.719(4)Å, respectively), indicating weaker bonding interactions. In addition, the phenyl rings in the macrocycle are arranged in a face-to-face mode by π⋯π stacking interaction (the distance between two aromatic planes is ca. 3.5Å), in sharp contrast to the C-H⋯π interactions found in 1 (c)

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st070">Synthesis and characterization of Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(L)(BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·0.25(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">The critical role played by the counter anion (nitrate ion) in bridging the silver(I) center to form the 2-D network in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> encouraged us to investigate the impact of other silver salts on the self-assembly process. We next examined the reaction between L and silver tetrafluoroborate under the same conditions as for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, and colorless crystals of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were obtained in moderate yield. IR spectrum of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows strong absorption as a broad band at around 3565<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, indicating the presence of water molecules. In addition, peaks appear at ca. 1028 and 519<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, consistent with the inclusion of BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> in the coordination compound. X-ray structural analysis identifies the main silver(I) network in the solid state, although several disorders were found (see Section  for details). <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group <ce:italic>I</ce:italic>mma and the asymmetric unit contains only one half of the ligand molecule. Unlike the case in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, two independent silver(I) centers that bind to the same sulfur atom through a μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-S bridging coordination are observed in the asymmetric unit of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>a). The silver binding mode resembles the type-C mode in , whereas the ligand belongs to the conformation II (). Ag1 is two-coordinate with two symmetry-related sulfur atoms from distinct ligands and adopts an almost linear geometry (the S–Ag1–S angle is 172.12(4)°). In contrast, Ag2 is tetra-coordinate with not only two symmetry-related sulfur atoms, but also oxygen atoms from two water molecules that were involved in the structure of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> during the reaction through a bis-μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-O bridging mode. The counter anions BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> that are, as expected, non-coordinated exist in the lattice. Thus, the coordination chemistry and the extended supramolecular structure in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are completely different from that in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, highlighting the drastic influence of counter anions.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis and characterization of Ag2(L)(BF4)2⋅0.25(H2O) (2)

The critical role played by the counter anion (nitrate ion) in bridging the silver(I) center to form the 2-D network in 1 encouraged us to investigate the impact of other silver salts on the self-assembly process. We next examined the reaction between L and silver tetrafluoroborate under the same conditions as for 1, and colorless crystals of 2 were obtained in moderate yield. IR spectrum of 2 shows strong absorption as a broad band at around 3565cm-1, indicating the presence of water molecules. In addition, peaks appear at ca. 1028 and 519cm-1, consistent with the inclusion of BF4 - in the coordination compound. X-ray structural analysis identifies the main silver(I) network in the solid state, although several disorders were found (see Section  for details). 2 crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Imma and the asymmetric unit contains only one half of the ligand molecule. Unlike the case in 1, two independent silver(I) centers that bind to the same sulfur atom through a μ2-S bridging coordination are observed in the asymmetric unit of 2 ( a). The silver binding mode resembles the type-C mode in , whereas the ligand belongs to the conformation II (). Ag1 is two-coordinate with two symmetry-related sulfur atoms from distinct ligands and adopts an almost linear geometry (the S-Ag1-S angle is 172.12(4)°). In contrast, Ag2 is tetra-coordinate with not only two symmetry-related sulfur atoms, but also oxygen atoms from two water molecules that were involved in the structure of 2 during the reaction through a bis-μ2-O bridging mode. The counter anions BF4 - that are, as expected, non-coordinated exist in the lattice. Thus, the coordination chemistry and the extended supramolecular structure in 2 are completely different from that in 1, highlighting the drastic influence of counter anions.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0065" view="all">In <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the Ag1–S1 bond is slightly shorter than that found in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (2.4193(9) vs. 2.5185(6)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), despite that Ag2–S and Ag2B–S bond lengths (2.5332(9) and 2.562(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively) are similar to those in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. Owing to the more complicated connectivity between the thioether ligands and silver(I) centers, bond expansion of the asymmetric unit in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> leads to the formation of a network with higher dimensionality (b and c). First of all, a macrocyle composed of two ligand molecules and two Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> cores is formed, whose structure is somehow close to that disclosed in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. Propagation of the macrocycles through ligand L results in an infinite 1-D structure that involves only Ag2 centers. Further expansion through the Ag1 cores and more ligand molecules towards two directions of the 1-D assembly affords a 3-D metal–organic framework in which up to nanoscale cavities are present. The BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> counter anions occupy some of the larger cavities (c). It should be noted that although BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ion did not participate in coordination with silver(I), both ligand conformation and binding mode have been affected by the existence of this anion during the reaction. In addition, the involvement of water molecules in the coordination event is also a key to the formation of framework of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> having a higher dimension. The 3D topological presentation of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> was generated by using TOPOS analysis  which suggests the 3D network could be better described as a uninodal {6^6} net (d) .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In 2, the Ag1-S1 bond is slightly shorter than that found in 1 (2.4193(9) vs. 2.5185(6)Å), despite that Ag2-S and Ag2B-S bond lengths (2.5332(9) and 2.562(3)Å, respectively) are similar to those in 1. Owing to the more complicated connectivity between the thioether ligands and silver(I) centers, bond expansion of the asymmetric unit in 2 leads to the formation of a network with higher dimensionality (b and c). First of all, a macrocyle composed of two ligand molecules and two Ag2O2 cores is formed, whose structure is somehow close to that disclosed in 1. Propagation of the macrocycles through ligand L results in an infinite 1-D structure that involves only Ag2 centers. Further expansion through the Ag1 cores and more ligand molecules towards two directions of the 1-D assembly affords a 3-D metal-organic framework in which up to nanoscale cavities are present. The BF4 - counter anions occupy some of the larger cavities (c). It should be noted that although BF4 - ion did not participate in coordination with silver(I), both ligand conformation and binding mode have been affected by the existence of this anion during the reaction. In addition, the involvement of water molecules in the coordination event is also a key to the formation of framework of 2 having a higher dimension. The 3D topological presentation of 2 was generated by using TOPOS analysis  which suggests the 3D network could be better described as a uninodal {6^6} net (d) .

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st075">Synthesis and characterization of Ag(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>) (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0070" view="all">Having disclosed the remarkable role the anions played in driving diverse supramolecular architectures, we further explored the anion effect on the Ag–L coordination chemistry, and used a larger anion hexafluorophosphate (PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>) for the reaction. Thus, the combination of L with 2.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>equiv. elements.clean_text:
Synthesis and characterization of Ag(L)2(PF6) (3)

Having disclosed the remarkable role the anions played in driving diverse supramolecular architectures, we further explored the anion effect on the Ag-L coordination chemistry, and used a larger anion hexafluorophosphate (PF6 -) for the reaction. Thus, the combination of L with 2.0equiv. AgPF6 under the same conditions for 1 and 2 afforded colorless crystals of 3 that were characterized by IR, elemental analysis and X-ray crystallography. Elemental analysis of the bulk sample reveals a metal-to-ligand ratio of 1:2, apparently different from those of 1 and 2, indicating new coordination chemistry in crystals of 3. The presence of PF6 - ion in the structure of 3 was confirmed by its IR spectrum showing characteristic stretching and bending at ca. 839 and 556cm-1. Indeed, X-ray structural analysis confirmed the formation of a novel 2-D network structure in 3 ( ). 3 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/n and in the asymmetric unit two independent ligand molecules are observed. In addition, one silver(I) center and one PF6 - ion are present (a). Interestingly, in 3 the silver(I) center adopts a S4 coordination environment with a pseudo-tetrahedral geometry, different from that observed in 1 and 2. Each silver(I) ion is ligated via four sulfur donors from four distinct ligands and meanwhile each ligand binds to two silver(I) ions to form an infinite 2-D grid-like structure that constitutes of square 4+4 metallomacrocycles (b and c). Two ligand molecules in the macrocycle of 3 adopt the same conformation I as shown in  and the metal binding belongs to the type-A pattern (). The 4+4 grid has a dimension of ca. 9.5×9.6Å2, and features a saddle-like shape. The two pairs of Ag⋯Ag distances between two Ag(I) centers in the grid are 9.513 and 9.647Å, respectively, and the four Ag(I) centers are well coplanar. One PF6 - ion resides in the center of each saddle-shaped grid. Ag-S bond lengths in 3 are close to those in 1. Bond expansion along the four Ag(I) centers of the grid leads to the assembly of a 2-D cationic network running down the ab direction, as shown in c. Again, the anion PF6 -, albeit non-coordinated, has governed the coordination and supramolecular assembly between silver(I) and L, and is completely responsible for the generation of the 2-D grid-like network in 3, in sharp contrast to the structures of 1 and 2.

<ce:section-title id="st080">Synthesis and characterization of Ag(L)(SbF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>)(NCCH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0075" view="all">Encouraged by the above findings of remarkable anion induction effect, finally, we studied the reaction by replacing PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> with its analog, a larger anion, hexafluoroantimonate (SbF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>). Accordingly, the same reaction conditions were applied and suitable crystals of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> were obtained from the reaction of L with AgSbF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>. The incorporation of acetonitrile molecules in the structure of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> was confirmed by the IR absorption at around 2290<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> and the strong peak at 556<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> indicates the presence of SbF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ions. Elemental analysis of bulk sample of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> also suggests a 1:1 metal–ligand ratio. X-ray crystallographic studies reveal a 1-D polymeric chain, distinct from all the above described structures. <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> crystallizes in the orthorhombic system with a <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> space group. Unlike <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the structure of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> was refined with a Flack parameter of 0.48(2), indicating a racemic twin existing in the cell of the crystal. The asymmetric unit contains one independent ligand, one Ag<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> (accompanied ion with one SbF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>), and two coordinated CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN molecules (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>a). Each Ag(I) is tetra-coordinate with two sulfur donors from two distinct ligands, and two nitrogen atoms from two CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN solvent molecules. Each ligand also coordinates with two symmetry-related Ag(I) centers. The Ag-S bond lengths are unexceptional to those in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, while the S–Ag–S angle is 135.73(3)° and N–Ag–N angle is 90.96(15)°, severely deviated from a tetrahedral silver coordination sphere. The ligand molecule features the conformation II and the Ag-L binding is consistent with type-A coordination mode (). Extension of the repeating structural unit along the crystallographic <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> axis results in the observation of an infinite 1-D polymeric chain (b), which is distinct with the 2- or 3-D networks as discussed above for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. Interestingly, chains propagate along the crystallographic <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> axis to form a helical structure and both the <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>- and <ce:italic>M</ce:italic>-helix were observed. This is consistent with the fact that the complex crystallizes as a racemic mixture. The pitch of helix is approximately 7.87<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, corresponding to the adjacent Ag⋯Ag separation in the chain. Compared to <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, although similar anions were used, the lower dimensionality of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> should be attributed to the coordination of solvent molecules (CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN) with silver(I), which prevents other ligands from accessing the silver(I) spheres and limits further dimensional expansion.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis and characterization of Ag(L)(SbF6)(NCCH3)2 (4)

Encouraged by the above findings of remarkable anion induction effect, finally, we studied the reaction by replacing PF6 - with its analog, a larger anion, hexafluoroantimonate (SbF6 -). Accordingly, the same reaction conditions were applied and suitable crystals of 4 were obtained from the reaction of L with AgSbF6. The incorporation of acetonitrile molecules in the structure of 4 was confirmed by the IR absorption at around 2290cm-1 and the strong peak at 556cm-1 indicates the presence of SbF6 - ions. Elemental analysis of bulk sample of 4 also suggests a 1:1 metal-ligand ratio. X-ray crystallographic studies reveal a 1-D polymeric chain, distinct from all the above described structures. 4 crystallizes in the orthorhombic system with a P212121 space group. Unlike 1, the structure of 4 was refined with a Flack parameter of 0.48(2), indicating a racemic twin existing in the cell of the crystal. The asymmetric unit contains one independent ligand, one Ag+ (accompanied ion with one SbF6 -), and two coordinated CH3CN molecules ( a). Each Ag(I) is tetra-coordinate with two sulfur donors from two distinct ligands, and two nitrogen atoms from two CH3CN solvent molecules. Each ligand also coordinates with two symmetry-related Ag(I) centers. The Ag-S bond lengths are unexceptional to those in 1-3, while the S-Ag-S angle is 135.73(3)° and N-Ag-N angle is 90.96(15)°, severely deviated from a tetrahedral silver coordination sphere. The ligand molecule features the conformation II and the Ag-L binding is consistent with type-A coordination mode (). Extension of the repeating structural unit along the crystallographic a axis results in the observation of an infinite 1-D polymeric chain (b), which is distinct with the 2- or 3-D networks as discussed above for 1-3. Interestingly, chains propagate along the crystallographic a axis to form a helical structure and both the P- and M-helix were observed. This is consistent with the fact that the complex crystallizes as a racemic mixture. The pitch of helix is approximately 7.87Å, corresponding to the adjacent Ag⋯Ag separation in the chain. Compared to 3, although similar anions were used, the lower dimensionality of 4 should be attributed to the coordination of solvent molecules (CH3CN) with silver(I), which prevents other ligands from accessing the silver(I) spheres and limits further dimensional expansion.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0080" view="all">It is worth mentioning that although L has been previously employed as a pincer-type SCS ligand to construct various complexes with precious metals (such as Pt and Pd) or silicon involving metal (or Si)–C bond formation , its silver(I) coordination chemistry observed here is essentially different. However, compared to relevant silver–thioether coordination complexes reported previously , the Ag–S coordination modes involved in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> are unexceptional.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: It is worth mentioning that although L has been previously employed as a pincer-type SCS ligand to construct various complexes with precious metals (such as Pt and Pd) or silicon involving metal (or Si)-C bond formation , its silver(I) coordination chemistry observed here is essentially different. However, compared to relevant silver-thioether coordination complexes reported previously , the Ag-S coordination modes involved in 1-4 are unexceptional.

<ce:section-title id="st085">Thermal properties</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0085" view="all">Thermal stability of four silver(I) coordination compounds were examined by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) under N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> atmosphere. The corresponding TG curves for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> are presented in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>. As shown in , compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is stable up to 179<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and then experiences decomposition in two stages (179–365<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and 500–645<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C) with a total weight loss of ca. 54.8%, owing to the removal of ligand molecules from the complex (calcd. 54.0%). Compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> undergoes a small weight loss (ca. 4.2%) between 50 and 147<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, accounting for the loss of water molecules from the 3D silver framework of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (ca. 1.5 H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O per unit, calcd. 4.4%), which is in agreement with the data of elemental analysis, indicating <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is hygroscopic in the air. <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is then decomposed upon heating to 196<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C by removing the ligand molecules. Compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> proves to be less thermostable and begins to decompose gradually from 163<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. In contrast, 4 is stable up to 212<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C at which temperature a slight weight loss (ca. 1.25%) is observed, consistent with the removal of two coordinated CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN molecules per structural unit (calcd. 1.3%). Again, upon further heating major decomposition of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> occurs at 234<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Thermal properties

Thermal stability of four silver(I) coordination compounds were examined by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) under N2 atmosphere. The corresponding TG curves for 1-4 are presented in  . As shown in , compound 1 is stable up to 179°C and then experiences decomposition in two stages (179-365°C and 500-645°C) with a total weight loss of ca. 54.8%, owing to the removal of ligand molecules from the complex (calcd. 54.0%). Compound 2 undergoes a small weight loss (ca. 4.2%) between 50 and 147°C, accounting for the loss of water molecules from the 3D silver framework of 2 (ca. 1.5 H2O per unit, calcd. 4.4%), which is in agreement with the data of elemental analysis, indicating 2 is hygroscopic in the air. 2 is then decomposed upon heating to 196°C by removing the ligand molecules. Compound 3 proves to be less thermostable and begins to decompose gradually from 163°C. In contrast, 4 is stable up to 212°C at which temperature a slight weight loss (ca. 1.25%) is observed, consistent with the removal of two coordinated CH3CN molecules per structural unit (calcd. 1.3%). Again, upon further heating major decomposition of 4 occurs at 234°C.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st090">Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0090" view="all">In conclusion, we have described the silver(I)-mediated assembly of four novel coordination polymers with diverse 1- to 3-D network structures based on a flexible thioether ligand, depending on the use of various anions in the silver salts. It was revealed that different counter anions (NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>, BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>, PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> and SbF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>) have played critical roles in regulating the formation of distinct metal–organic architectures, although the same reaction conditions were applied. The structural diversity of 1- to 3-D networks observed in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> highlights the effect of anion variation on the silver-thioether coordination networks. Further investigations are directed towards relevant coordination polymers of thioethers with different ligand backbones.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, we have described the silver(I)-mediated assembly of four novel coordination polymers with diverse 1- to 3-D network structures based on a flexible thioether ligand, depending on the use of various anions in the silver salts. It was revealed that different counter anions (NO3 -, BF4 -, PF6 - and SbF6 -) have played critical roles in regulating the formation of distinct metal-organic architectures, although the same reaction conditions were applied. The structural diversity of 1- to 3-D networks observed in 1-4 highlights the effect of anion variation on the silver-thioether coordination networks. Further investigations are directed towards relevant coordination polymers of thioethers with different ligand backbones.

Synthesis of Ag(L)(NO3)(1)

Ligand L (19.8mg, 0.100mmol) was dissolved in CH2Cl2-MeCN (10mL, 1:1, v/v) in a 25mL vial, to which an acetonitrile solution of AgNO3 (33.8mg, 0.200mmol) was added upon stirring at room temperature. The resulting solution was allowed to stir for 30min and then filtered. Slow evaporation of the filtrate over 5days gave colorless crystals, which were suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis. The product was collected by decanting the solvent and then washed with diethyl ether, and dried in the air. Yield: 30.9mg (84% based on L). FT-IR (solid, cm-1): 2921w, 1432m, 1405s, 1277s, 1155w, 1083w, 1023m, 990w, 908w, 815s, 730s, 669w, 599w. Anal. Calc. for C10H14AgNO3S2⋅0.2CH2Cl2: C, 31.80; H, 3.77; N, 3.64. Found C, 31.79; H, 3.60; N, 3.87%.

Synthesis of Ag2(L)(BF4)2⋅0.25(H2O) (2)

The procedure was similar to that for 1, except for the replacement of AgNO3 with AgBF4 (38.8mg, 0.200mmol). After one week, colorless crystals of 2 were collected by filtration, washed with diethyl ether and dried in the air. Yield: 37.0mg (61%). FT-IR (solid, cm-1): 3565br, 1627m, 1427m, 1288w, 1028s, 819m, 725s, 654w, 556m, 519m. Anal. Calc. for C10H14Ag2B2F3S2⋅1.5H2O: C, 19.54; H, 2.79. Found: C, 19.16; H, 2.82%.

Synthesis of Ag(L)2(PF6) (3)

The procedure is similar to that for 1, except for the replacement of AgNO3 with AgPF6 (50.4mg, 0.200mmol). After one week, colorless crystals of 3 were collected by filtration, washed with diethyl ether and dried in the air. Yield: 27.5mg (85% based on L). FT-IR (solid, cm-1): 1636m, 1534m, 1484m, 1449s, 1379s, 1338s, 1290s, 1214m, 1150m, 1074m, 1034w, 929w, 839w, 779m, 753m, 601m, 556m. Anal. Calcd. for C20H28AgF6PS4: C, 36.98; H, 4.35. Found: C, 36.87; H, 4.24%.

Synthesis of Ag(L)(SbF6)(NCCH3)2 (4)

The procedure is similar to that for 1, except for the replacement of AgNO3 with AgSbF6 (68.4mg, 0.200mmol). After one week, colorless crystals of 4 were collected by filtration, washed with diethyl ether and dried in the air. Yield: 47.8mg (77% based on L). FT-IR (solid, cm-1): 2929w, 2290m, 1484w, 1431s, 1326w, 1230w, 1162w, 1086w, 986m, 815s, 723s, 655s, 597w. Anal. Calcd. for C14H20AgF6N2S2Sb: C, 26.94; H, 3.23; N, 4.49. Found: C, 27.12; H, 3.44; N 4.39%.

Synthesis and characterization of Ag(L)2(PF6) (3)

Having disclosed the remarkable role the anions played in driving diverse supramolecular architectures, we further explored the anion effect on the Ag-L coordination chemistry, and used a larger anion hexafluorophosphate (PF6 -) for the reaction. Thus, the combination of L with 2.0equiv. AgPF6 under the same conditions for 1 and 2 afforded colorless crystals of 3 that were characterized by IR, elemental analysis and X-ray crystallography. Elemental analysis of the bulk sample reveals a metal-to-ligand ratio of 1:2, apparently different from those of 1 and 2, indicating new coordination chemistry in crystals of 3. The presence of PF6 - ion in the structure of 3 was confirmed by its IR spectrum showing characteristic stretching and bending at ca. 839 and 556cm-1. Indeed, X-ray structural analysis confirmed the formation of a novel 2-D network structure in 3 ( ). 3 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/n and in the asymmetric unit two independent ligand molecules are observed. In addition, one silver(I) center and one PF6 - ion are present (a). Interestingly, in 3 the silver(I) center adopts a S4 coordination environment with a pseudo-tetrahedral geometry, different from that observed in 1 and 2. Each silver(I) ion is ligated via four sulfur donors from four distinct ligands and meanwhile each ligand binds to two silver(I) ions to form an infinite 2-D grid-like structure that constitutes of square 4+4 metallomacrocycles (b and c). Two ligand molecules in the macrocycle of 3 adopt the same conformation I as shown in  and the metal binding belongs to the type-A pattern (). The 4+4 grid has a dimension of ca. 9.5×9.6Å2, and features a saddle-like shape. The two pairs of Ag⋯Ag distances between two Ag(I) centers in the grid are 9.513 and 9.647Å, respectively, and the four Ag(I) centers are well coplanar. One PF6 - ion resides in the center of each saddle-shaped grid. Ag-S bond lengths in 3 are close to those in 1. Bond expansion along the four Ag(I) centers of the grid leads to the assembly of a 2-D cationic network running down the ab direction, as shown in c. Again, the anion PF6 -, albeit non-coordinated, has governed the coordination and supramolecular assembly between silver(I) and L, and is completely responsible for the generation of the 2-D grid-like network in 3, in sharp contrast to the structures of 1 and 2.

cln_elements.clean_text:
The reaction of L with two equivalents of silver nitrate in a CH2Cl2-MeCN solution afforded after slow evaporation colorless crystals of 1 in high yield, that are suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis. Elemental analysis data reveals an empirical formula of Ag(L)NO3, suggesting a 1:1 metal-to-ligand ratio in 1. 1 is poorly soluble in common solvents, and slightly soluble in dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO). The 1HH NMR spectrum of 1 in DMSO-d 6 reveals only signals identical to those of the free ligand, indicating the decomposition of the complex in DMSO. In the IR spectrum of 1 a strong band at around 1405cm-1 appeared due to the coordinated NO3 - ions. X-ray structural analysis confirmed the formation of a coordination network involving effective Ag-S binding in the solid state ( ). 1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Cmc21 and in the asymmetric unit there contains only one half of ligand L, one silver ion and nitrate anion, and the second half of L was generated by symmetry (operation code: -x, y, z). The Flack parameter of crystal 1 having a acentric space group was refined to be -0.01(2), indicating 1 crystallizes as an enantiopure form, although achiral ligand was used. It was noticed that as seen in a the ligand molecules in 1 adopt the conformation I and type-A binding mode with two silver(I) centers related by a C 2 symmetric axis (). Relevant bond parameters around metal centers are summarized in  . The silver(I) center is tetracoordinate with two sulfur atoms from symmetry-related ligands and two oxygen atoms of the bridging nitrate ions, being in a slightly distorted tetrahedral environment. The Ag-S bond distances are almost identical (2.5185(6) and 2.5186(6)Å, respectively), falling in the range of Ag-S bond lengths reported in the literature , yet the Ag-O bonds are slightly different in length (2.357(3) and 2.533(3)Å). Propagation of the repeat structure unit along the silver(II) centers results in the formation of an infinite 2-D coordination network which is composed of 20-membered macrocycles containing two ligand units, two silver(I) centers and two bridging nitrato-O atoms (b and c). In each macrocycle, the Ag⋯Ag nonbonding distance between two silver(I) centers bonded to the same ligand is approximately 10.7Å, while the O-bridged Ag⋯Ag nonbonding distance is approximately 4.6Å. The two phenyl rings of ligands in the macrocycle are arranged in an edge-to-face fashion and thus effective C-H⋯π interaction is observed between the rings. The C-H⋯ π (centroid) distance as illustrated in c is as short as ca. 2.85Å (c). It is worth mentioning that previously a silver(I) perchlorate complex based on a similar thioether ligand, 1,3-bis(phenylthiomethyl)benzene has been reported, where a structurally related grid-like network was observed . However, the structure of the repeating macrocyclic motif in this network is essentially distinct with that of 1. In the structure reported previously , the silver centers are bridged by two oxygen atoms of the perchlorate anion, and the Ag-O bond distances are relatively longer (2.556(10) and 2.719(4)Å, respectively), indicating weaker bonding interactions. In addition, the phenyl rings in the macrocycle are arranged in a face-to-face mode by π⋯π stacking interaction (the distance between two aromatic planes is ca. 3.5Å), in sharp contrast to the C-H⋯π interactions found in 1 (c)

Synthesis and characterization of Ag2(L)(BF4)2⋅0.25(H2O) (2)

The critical role played by the counter anion (nitrate ion) in bridging the silver(I) center to form the 2-D network in 1 encouraged us to investigate the impact of other silver salts on the self-assembly process. We next examined the reaction between L and silver tetrafluoroborate under the same conditions as for 1, and colorless crystals of 2 were obtained in moderate yield. IR spectrum of 2 shows strong absorption as a broad band at around 3565cm-1, indicating the presence of water molecules. In addition, peaks appear at ca. 1028 and 519cm-1, consistent with the inclusion of BF4 - in the coordination compound. X-ray structural analysis identifies the main silver(I) network in the solid state, although several disorders were found (see Section  for details). 2 crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Imma and the asymmetric unit contains only one half of the ligand molecule. Unlike the case in 1, two independent silver(I) centers that bind to the same sulfur atom through a μ2-S bridging coordination are observed in the asymmetric unit of 2 ( a). The silver binding mode resembles the type-C mode in , whereas the ligand belongs to the conformation II (). Ag1 is two-coordinate with two symmetry-related sulfur atoms from distinct ligands and adopts an almost linear geometry (the S-Ag1-S angle is 172.12(4)°). In contrast, Ag2 is tetra-coordinate with not only two symmetry-related sulfur atoms, but also oxygen atoms from two water molecules that were involved in the structure of 2 during the reaction through a bis-μ2-O bridging mode. The counter anions BF4 - that are, as expected, non-coordinated exist in the lattice. Thus, the coordination chemistry and the extended supramolecular structure in 2 are completely different from that in 1, highlighting the drastic influence of counter anions.

Synthesis and characterization of Ag(L)(SbF6)(NCCH3)2 (4)

Encouraged by the above findings of remarkable anion induction effect, finally, we studied the reaction by replacing PF6 - with its analog, a larger anion, hexafluoroantimonate (SbF6 -). Accordingly, the same reaction conditions were applied and suitable crystals of 4 were obtained from the reaction of L with AgSbF6. The incorporation of acetonitrile molecules in the structure of 4 was confirmed by the IR absorption at around 2290cm-1 and the strong peak at 556cm-1 indicates the presence of SbF6 - ions. Elemental analysis of bulk sample of 4 also suggests a 1:1 metal-ligand ratio. X-ray crystallographic studies reveal a 1-D polymeric chain, distinct from all the above described structures. 4 crystallizes in the orthorhombic system with a P212121 space group. Unlike 1, the structure of 4 was refined with a Flack parameter of 0.48(2), indicating a racemic twin existing in the cell of the crystal. The asymmetric unit contains one independent ligand, one Ag+ (accompanied ion with one SbF6 -), and two coordinated CH3CN molecules ( a). Each Ag(I) is tetra-coordinate with two sulfur donors from two distinct ligands, and two nitrogen atoms from two CH3CN solvent molecules. Each ligand also coordinates with two symmetry-related Ag(I) centers. The Ag-S bond lengths are unexceptional to those in 1-3, while the S-Ag-S angle is 135.73(3)° and N-Ag-N angle is 90.96(15)°, severely deviated from a tetrahedral silver coordination sphere. The ligand molecule features the conformation II and the Ag-L binding is consistent with type-A coordination mode (). Extension of the repeating structural unit along the crystallographic a axis results in the observation of an infinite 1-D polymeric chain (b), which is distinct with the 2- or 3-D networks as discussed above for 1-3. Interestingly, chains propagate along the crystallographic a axis to form a helical structure and both the P- and M-helix were observed. This is consistent with the fact that the complex crystallizes as a racemic mixture. The pitch of helix is approximately 7.87Å, corresponding to the adjacent Ag⋯Ag separation in the chain. Compared to 3, although similar anions were used, the lower dimensionality of 4 should be attributed to the coordination of solvent molecules (CH3CN) with silver(I), which prevents other ligands from accessing the silver(I) spheres and limits further dimensional expansion.

Thermal properties

Thermal stability of four silver(I) coordination compounds were examined by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) under N2 atmosphere. The corresponding TG curves for 1-4 are presented in  . As shown in , compound 1 is stable up to 179°C and then experiences decomposition in two stages (179-365°C and 500-645°C) with a total weight loss of ca. 54.8%, owing to the removal of ligand molecules from the complex (calcd. 54.0%). Compound 2 undergoes a small weight loss (ca. 4.2%) between 50 and 147°C, accounting for the loss of water molecules from the 3D silver framework of 2 (ca. 1.5 H2O per unit, calcd. 4.4%), which is in agreement with the data of elemental analysis, indicating 2 is hygroscopic in the air. 2 is then decomposed upon heating to 196°C by removing the ligand molecules. Compound 3 proves to be less thermostable and begins to decompose gradually from 163°C. In contrast, 4 is stable up to 212°C at which temperature a slight weight loss (ca. 1.25%) is observed, consistent with the removal of two coordinated CH3CN molecules per structural unit (calcd. 1.3%). Again, upon further heating major decomposition of 4 occurs at 234°C.

decomposition temperature.type: removal of two coordinated CH3CN molecules

<ce:figure id="f0005">
<ce:label>Fig. 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="cn0005">
<ce:simple-para id="sp0020" view="all">(a) The ORTEP representation of crystal structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> with thermal ellipsoid at 30% probability level. H atoms are omitted for clarity (b) The 2-D network found in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (an O–Ag–O chain is highlighted by ball-stick representation). (c) The 20-membered macrocycles composed of four silver(I) centers showing aromatic C–H⋯π contact.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link id="lk00005" locator="gr1" xlink:href="pii:S0277538716306428/gr1" xlink:role="http://data.elsevier.com/vocabulary/ElsevierContentTypes/23.4" xlink:type="simple"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
cln_elements.clean_text: Fig. 1  (a) The ORTEP representation of crystal structure of 1 with thermal ellipsoid at 30% probability level. H atoms are omitted for clarity (b) The 2-D network found in 1 (an O-Ag-O chain is highlighted by ball-stick representation). (c) The 20-membered macrocycles composed of four silver(I) centers showing aromatic C-H⋯π contact.

cln_elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0010">
<ce:label>Fig. 2</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="cn0010">
<ce:simple-para id="sp0025" view="all">(a) The ORTEP representation of partial structure of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> with thermal ellipsoid at 30% probability level. H atoms are omitted for clarity. (b) The 2-D coordination network revealed in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. (c) The 3-D framework found in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> viewing down the crystallographic <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> axis. (d) A TOPOS representation of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> showing a uninodal {6^6} net.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link id="lk00010" locator="gr2" xlink:href="pii:S0277538716306428/gr2" xlink:role="http://data.elsevier.com/vocabulary/ElsevierContentTypes/23.4" xlink:type="simple"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
cln_elements.clean_text: Fig. 2  (a) The ORTEP representation of partial structure of 2 with thermal ellipsoid at 30% probability level. H atoms are omitted for clarity. (b) The 2-D coordination network revealed in 2. (c) The 3-D framework found in 2 viewing down the crystallographic c axis. (d) A TOPOS representation of 2 showing a uninodal {6^6} net.

cln_elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0015">
<ce:label>Fig. 3</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="cn0015">
<ce:simple-para id="sp0030" view="all">(a) ORTEP representation of the repeating unit in the network of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> with ellipsoids plotted at the 30% probability level. H atoms are omitted for clarity. (b) Ball-stick representation for one of the saddle-like grid containing a PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anion in the center. (c) Part of the 2-D grid-like network observed in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions are omitted for clarity.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link id="lk00015" locator="gr3" xlink:href="pii:S0277538716306428/gr3" xlink:role="http://data.elsevier.com/vocabulary/ElsevierContentTypes/23.4" xlink:type="simple"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
cln_elements.clean_text: Fig. 3  (a) ORTEP representation of the repeating unit in the network of 3 with ellipsoids plotted at the 30% probability level. H atoms are omitted for clarity. (b) Ball-stick representation for one of the saddle-like grid containing a PF6 - anion in the center. (c) Part of the 2-D grid-like network observed in 3. PF6 - anions are omitted for clarity.

cln_elements.content:

<ce:caption id="cn0020">
<ce:simple-para id="sp0035" view="all">(a) The repeat unit in the crystal structure of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> with ellipsoids plotted at the 50% probability level. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. (b) One of the racemic helical chains (<ce:italic>M-</ce:italic>helix) found in the structure of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, and the helical chain is highlighted with red color. (Colour online.)</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link id="lk00020" locator="gr4" xlink:href="pii:S0277538716306428/gr4" xlink:role="http://data.elsevier.com/vocabulary/ElsevierContentTypes/23.4" xlink:type="simple"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
cln_elements.clean_text: Fig. 4  (a) The repeat unit in the crystal structure of 4 with ellipsoids plotted at the 50% probability level. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. (b) One of the racemic helical chains (M-helix) found in the structure of 4, and the helical chain is highlighted with red color. (Colour online.)
